item.title: Pokemon Pocket: The Best Metal-Type Deck
item.description:
Quick Links

  • The Best Metal Deck in the Current Meta
  • The Best Experimental Metal Deck
  • Current Performance of Metal Decks in Pocket’s Meta
  • Why Metal Decks Have Failed in Pocket’s Meta
  • How to Counter Metal Decks

Since Pokemon Pocket launched, the Metal archetype has been the least favored of all the types. While many players have tried to build competitive decks around it, most have failed, and the metagame has yet to see a truly successful Metal-type deck.

That said, there’s still room for creativity. Recent Metal decks, particularly those refined with Mythical Island cards, have shown potential. In this guide, I’ll walk you through building two of these decks, which use Pokemon Pocket ’s new cards to offset the archetype’s below-average stats.

The Best Metal Deck in the Current Meta

To build a consistent Metal deck, limit your Pokemon to three: Meltan, Melmetal, and Druddigon. Use Meltan to accelerate Energy, stall with Druddigon, and deal damage with Melmetal. Fill the rest of the deck with Trainer Cards to improve draw rates.

Here's how to build the Melmetal-Druddigon deck:

The Best Experimental Metal Deck

Recent tournaments saw the rise of a new Metal deck that caught many meta decks off guard: the Melmetal-Greninja deck , supported by Druddigon. And it’s one of the most promising setups for the Metal archetype.

The deck’s concept is simple: Place Druddigon in the frontline to stall. Build up Meltan, which evolves into Melmetal. Once Melmetal is ready to attack, start dealing damage. Meanwhile, keep Greninja on the Bench to provide additional chip damage, helping to make up for Melmetal’s below-average output.

You won’t need to add Water-type Energy to the Melmetal & Greninja deck, as Greninja stays on the Bench and only applies chip damage with its Energy-free ability.

Current Performance of Metal Decks in Pocket’s Meta

I analyzed ten recent Pokemon Pocket tournaments focusing on the number of players using a Metal deck. My research shows that Metal-type setups appeared in 40% of the matches, with an average ranking of 66.2. In other words, Metal decks didn’t make it into the top 50.

The only tournament where a Melmetal deck performed well was one that landed in 12th place. In all other cases, the Metal decks I reviewed either conceded or ranked below 40.

Why Metal Decks Have Failed in Pocket’s Meta

There are two major issues with the Metal archetype in Pokemon Pocket ’s current meta: 1) There aren’t many Metal-type Pokemon, and 2) Only a few Pokemon are weak to Metal, and none of them are meta cards. This leaves you with a small pool to build from and a loss of type advantage, which is why Metal decks often fail.

However, Metal-type decks could gain popularity with upcoming expansions. New cards could address both issues: introducing more meta-friendly Metal Pokemon and adding more meta-affecting Pokemon that are weak to Metal.

How to Counter Metal Decks

In the current metagame, all Metal Pokemon in Pocket are weak to Fire-type decks. As a result, basic Charizard ex or Arcanine ex decks could be highly effective against them. Generally, though, fast-build lineups, like Pikachu ex decks, perform well against the slow-paced Metal setups.

item.title: The First Berserker: Khazan - Minimum & Recommended System Requirement
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Minimum System Requirements For The First Berserker: Khazan
  • Recommended System Requirements For The First Berserker: Khazan

The First Berserker: Khazan is an upcoming Soulslike game based on the iconic Dungeon & Fighter universe. The game is set to release on all major platforms in the coming months. While console players won’t need to worry about hardware, PC players must ensure their system meets the requirements.

A free demo is currently available for download on Steam, giving players a chance to try the game before its release. However, before downloading, you should check the system requirements to ensure your PC can run the game. The guide below provides exactly that information.

Related
How Are You Enjoying The First Berserker: Khazan's New Demo?

I haven't been able to boot it up yet, but I'm pretty excited to try it out. Excited for anything Ben Starr is in since his awesome performance as Clive in Final Fantasy 16.

Minimum System Requirements For The First Berserker: Khazan

PC Specs

Minimum Requirements

Target FPS and Resolution

1080p @ 30 FPS with Low Settings

OS

Windows 10 64-bit

Processor

Intel Core i3-6300 or AMD Ryzen 3 1200

Memory

12 GB RAM

Graphics

GeForce GTX 970 or Radeon RX 580 or Arc A580

Storage

70 GB SSD

If you're not too concerned about high frame rates or graphics settings, you'll be pleased to know that even decade-old hardware is supported. The minimum CPU requirements are an Intel Core i3-6300 or an AMD Ryzen 3 1200, paired with a GeForce GTX 970 or Radeon RX 580. For those with Intel GPUs, an Arc A580 or better is required.

The game also requires 12 GB of RAM and 70 GB of free storage, the latter of which should be an SSD. With this setup, you can expect to run the game at 1080p resolution, 30 FPS, with Low Graphics Settings.

  • Like most modern games, The First Berserker: Khazan requires Windows 10 64-bit at a minimum. However, for the best performance, the developer recommends using Windows 11.

Recommended System Requirements For The First Berserker: Khazan

PC Specs

Minimum Requirements

Target FPS and Resolution

1080p @ 60 FPS with High Settings

OS

Windows 11 64-bit

Processor

Intel Core i7-6700K or AMD Ryzen 5 3600

Memory

16 GB RAM

Graphics

GeForce RTX 2070 or Radeon RX 5700XT or Arc A750

Storage

70 GB SSD

If 30 FPS isn’t sufficient and you need at least 60 FPS with High Graphics Settings, you'll need more powerful hardware. While the storage requirement remains at 70 GB (preferably on an SSD), the RAM requirement increases to 16 GB.

For the CPU, you'll need an Intel Core i7-6700K or an AMD Ryzen 5 3600. The GPU requirements also jump to an RTX 2070 or a Radeon RX 5700 XT. If you’re using an Intel GPU, an Arc A750 or better will be necessary.

item.title: Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 Reveals Update Plans
item.description:
Summary

  • Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 released a second patch, Build 117, adding features like player level in multiplayer HUD.
  • Developer Crackshell targets fixing multiplayer connectivity issues and adding modding support in the future.

Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 developer Crackshell has released a second patch for the roguelike action RPG just a few days after its first update since release. Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 ’s first patch deployed Build 115 on January 15, fixing a wide array of niche issues and supplying added features and adjustments based on player feedback. The team also highlighted they were working on fixing more serious bugs as soon as possible, but the first patch was designed to fix some of the simpler things first.

There’s a host of anticipated games releasing in 2025, and Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 paved the way for a year of exciting releases after debuting on January 14. The sequel’s predecessor was released in March 2018 to tremendous praise, and multiplayer previously supported three-player gameplay, whereas the sequel has increased to four players.

Posted on the game’s Steam page, Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 ’s second patch welcomed Build 117 and welcomed a handful of new features, including adding the player level to the multiplayer HUD element, adding missing combo descriptions to the library menu, and added confirm prompts when exiting a game. Several bugs were also fixed, including issues where clients could take a trinket meant for the host and the Thunderbird giving damage when players spawned. It’s relatively simple to unlock all the characters in Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 , and another bug fixes an issue where a multiplier client could create a character based on what classes were unlocked by the host.

Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 Receives Second Patch and Brief Update Roadmap

2024 hosted a sea of impressive rougelike and roguelite games, including Hades 2 and Nordic Ashes: Survivors of Ragnarok , and Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 has gotten off to an impressive start in 2025 with “Very Positive” reviews on Steam. In terms of the game’s roadmap, the developer touched on further updates within the second patch, saying there isn’t a proper roadmap in place, but the team is prioritizing player feedback, multiplayer connectivity issues, and modding support starting with translations.

Joining a sea of randomly generated levels and impeccable customization, the players' main objective is to battle through the Dark Citadel, to obtain powerful equipment and items that open up new upgrades and abilities. Despite being the main location of the game, the Dark Citadel can only be unlocked later in Heroes of Hammerwatch 2 ’s gameplay, but once open, no two runs progress the same to keep gameplay fresh, and each completed expedition aids the upgrade of players’ towns, gear, and characters.

item.title: Best Games Like Simpsons Tapped Out
item.description:
Summary

  • "City builder games like RollerCoaster Tycoon Touch offer quest-based gameplay similar to The Simpson's Tapped Out."
  • "SimCity BuildIt provides a realistic city-building experience for players who prefer some realism in their mobile games."
  • "Games like Family Guy: The Quest For Stuff offer constantly updating content to keep players engaged and entertained."

Players have been looking for something to fill the hole left behind as a longstanding Simpson's game bows out. As sad as it is to lose an iconic mobile game like The Simpson's Tapped Out , there is a long list of similar games to distract and delight. While one of the best features of a city builder is the satisfaction of a well-designed layout, something else drew players to The Simpson's Tapped Out.

The sense of comfort and familiarity players get from rebuilding such an iconic fictional town was a real draw for Tapped Out players. With that in mind, the following recommendations bring similar mobile games featuring childhood favorites, iconic characters, and some seriously addictive gameplay!

Updated on January 19, 2025, by Mehrdad Khayyat: City-builder still remains one of the most beloved genres on mobile, as the gameplay mechanics just fit this platform perfectly. All players do in these games is to collect resources and then spend them on expanding the city.

There is always a desire in players to see what's next for the city. What will the next upgrade to a building look like? What else can be built to make the city look more awesome? How about changing the layout? All these questions just make players come back and follow their progression every day.

13 RollerCoaster Tycoon Touch

Create And Manage An Exciting Theme Park

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: February 22, 2017
  • Developer(s): Nivizzio Creations
  • Genre(s): Simulation, Strategy Video Game

RollerCoaster Tycoon Touch has all the excitement of the original RollerCoaster Tycoon in a neat mobile game package. As a building sim and management tycoon game, it has similar quest-based gameplay to The Simpson's Tapped Out . Players can place buildings and rides wherever they like, and add decor to boost any nearby ride's value.

A RollerCoaster Tycoon Touch park just keeps growing thanks to the continuous quests, new rides, and booths to add. Managing the ever-expanding theme park will get more intense as players progress - the bigger the theme park, the more can go wrong! RollerCoaster Tycoon Touch is a colorful, fun, never-ending, addictive game with a surprising amount of detail for a mobile title.

12 SimCity BuildIt

Create A Stunning Metropolis

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: October 22, 2014
  • Developer(s): Tracktwenty
  • Genre(s): City-building, Strategy Video Game

For mobile gamers who want what The Simpson's Tapped Out has to offer but prefer some realism, there is SimCity BuildIt. Based on the popular city-building game SimCity , this is a simplified (but not easy!) version of the original title. Creating a city from scratch is a tough job but, luckily, players have everything to hand that a decent mayor could wish for. The choice of layout and landmarks is entirely up to the individual player but just don't neglect the welfare of the citizens!

At first, players are guided by Simlish-speaking helpers but eventually, the world-building is all their own. Once the city is growing, the real excitement starts. Players can visit other mayors in their cities and team up to help each other create amazing cities. There is the chance to compete too, and defend against incoming dangers! Some players like to create amazing fantasy cities, while others love to recreate existing skylines like Tokyo or London. It is easy to spend hours perfecting a dream city in SimCity BuiltIt.

11 My Cruise: Idle Ship Tycoon

Build A Luxury Ship And Help Travelers Have Fun

  • Platform(s): Android
  • Release: December 14, 2023
  • Developer(s): Focus Apps
  • Genre(s): Management, Tycoon

While most builder games focus on cities, this game lets players to a luxury cruise ship with hundreds of travelers. It didn't take My Cruise: Idle Ship Tycoon to become immensely popular on mobile platforms, thanks to its creative approach. It's quite important to impress the guests in this game and increase the ship's reputation.

The sky is the limit for how many upgrades can be applied to a cruise ship, but the downside is the heavy grind. Similar to most games in this list, there is a progression accelerator in My Cruise: Idle Ship Tycoon too, and those who decide to ignore it will have a long way to go to the higher levels. However, for patient players, that shouldn't be a problem.

10 Fallout Shelter

Save Humanity From Extinction

Fallout Shelter brings the perilous fun of Fallout to mobile so players can build their very own post-apocalyptic bunker. The game starts simply: players must build rooms and provide power, water, and food to the vault dwellers. Soon, however, it becomes a careful balance between saving more wastelanders and saving resources.

After leveling up, players can explore the Wasteland in Fallout Shelter in the hope of discovering junk and caps. The real excitement comes when the Overseer sends players on quests to win exclusive gear and weapons, blueprints, and Nuka Cola. Fallout Shelter has all the addictive qualities of The Simpsons Tapped Out but with extra post-apocalyptic adventures! Gamers don't have to be fans of Fallout already, but there are plenty of easter eggs to make the game extra special for those who do.

9 Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp C

Explore and Decorate The Great Outdoors

Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp C is perfect for players who loved the task list element of The Simpson's Tapped Out. Of course, there is also a lot of fun decorating and design with Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp C but the real fun lies in growing the friendships with the animals around the camp.

As is also the case with games like The Simpsons Tapped Out, each new season brings new themes and items with which to decorate the camp. This keeps the great outdoor camping experience fresh and interesting! Every week, players can take on new tasks and help their animal friends with interesting challenges. Unlike city-builders, this Animal Crossing game has more of an adventure life sim feel to it and is worth trying for the cozy, casual vibes players may be seeking.

8 Smurfs' Village

Grow The Perfect Smurf Paradise

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: November 10, 2010
  • Developer(s): Capcom Interactive
  • Genre(s): Simulation, Management

The poor little Smurfs have been lost throughout the land thanks to the evil Gargamel. Players must help Papa Smurf and the rest of the gang adventure through the forest to find them all. As the Smurf population grows, it is up to the player to rebuild the Smurfs' Village with cute mushroom houses and farmland.

Just like The Simpsons Tapped Out, there are tasks to complete by each Smurf villager, from planting crops to repairing buildings. A bonus of Smurfs' Village is that players don't just have to simply tap to complete some tasks - there are mini-games to play too. Whether it is Whack-A-Smurf or a speedy baking game, there is so much to do in the Smurfs' Village.

7 American Dad! Apocalypse Soon

The Smith Family Needs Help

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: October 20, 2019
  • Developer(s): MY COM
  • Genre(s): RPG, Base-Building, Strategy

Aliens have landed in Langley Falls and the Smith family have turned their house into an operations base. Players must build new rooms and create powerful Roger clones to fight for the fate of the Earth. American Dad! Apocalypse Soon is an exciting mix of RPG fighting game and builder game where players must balance creating a huge bunker, manage the clone army, and send them out on missions.

Much like in The Simpsons Tapped Out, players get addictive character quests and city-building elements, all combined with PvP and PvE battles. American Dad! Apocalypse is packed with the same humor as the TV show and is a special treat for fans of the alien Roger as he takes center stage in much of the action!

6 Family Guy: The Quest For Stuff

Rebuild Quahog With The Griffin Family

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: April 10, 2014
  • Developer(s): TinyCo
  • Genre(s): City-building

From one iconic cartoon family to another, fans of The Simpson's Tapped Out may appreciate this city-builder based on the irreverent adult cartoon, Family Guy . Family Guy: The Quest For Stuff is constantly updating with new content to keep players coming back. Just like Tapped Out, the voice lines are all performed by the talented cast of the hit TV show, which is a real treat for die-hard fans.

Family Guy: The Quest For Stuff has so much in common with Tapped Out, starting with the basic premise. In both games, the main patriarch (in this case, Peter Griffin) has accidentally destroyed the town, and it is down to them to rebuild and bring everyone back. Family Guy: The Quest For Stuff has quest upon quest for players to complete to unlock each character and fill the town once again.

5 Disney Magic Kingdoms

Build A Unique Disney Park

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android, PC
  • Release: March 16, 2016
  • Developer(s): Gameloft
  • Genre(s): City-building, Strategy Video Game

Everyone's favorite Evil Queen has drawn a dark veil over the Disney Kingdom, and it is up to the player to break the curse! Mickey Mouse and Goofy are the first to arrive at the scene and begin to look for their friends. Soon, the park fills with childhood favorites like Woody from Toy Story, and Rapunzel from Tangled.

Disney Magic Kingdoms combines the wonder of Disney with the addictive gameplay of a city-builder. It has all the essential elements of a city-builder like The Simpsons Tapped Out but with a few fun rollercoaster sim features. The recognizable Disney themes that play when each character is selected are delightful, and the task-based gameplay is as addictive as players may expect!

4 Spongebob Adventures: In A Jam

Clean Up Bikini Bottom

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: September 26, 2023
  • Developer(s): Whaleapp
  • Genre(s): City-builder

Spongebob Adventures is another adventure sim game based on a popular 90s cartoon just like Tapped Out. Another of Plankton's dastardly plans has backfired, and it is up to the two hapless heroes, Spongebob and Patrick, to save Bikini Bottom. Just like The Simpsons Tapped Out, there are areas to uncover as players progress and well-known characters to unlock. Spongebob and Patrick's tasks are almost endless, from clearing debris to growing crops and crafting jellyfish food.

Unlike Tapped Out, there seems to be more variety in Spongebob Adventures, plus Bikini Bottom takes less time to clear up than Springfield! Players can visit new locations like the Jellyfish Fields to uncover treats and top up energy, so Spongebob and Patrick can continue with their mission to tidy up their town.

3 Brixity

Combine Blueprints And Create New Worlds With Playable Activities

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: August 18, 2023
  • Developer(s): Devsisters Corporation
  • Genre(s): Sandbox

As a creative playground, Brixity is one of those rare games that actually allow players to do whatever they want. It's more of a pocket Minecraft , where players use Blueprints to craft unique buildings and locations that also have a purpose.

That being said, it's not that simple. The main problem with Brixity is that players can only access a certain series of Blueprints with the base version, as the other series remain behind a paywall. Of course, it's worth it for those willing to pay, as a new pack of Blueprints delivers tons of new ideas to life.

Aside from the builder side, Brixity also allows players to customize their characters and engage with the created buildings through a variety of activities. Like racing circuits that allow players to compete against each other.

2 Goosebumps Horror Town

Fill The Town With Monsters

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: January 19, 2018
  • Developer(s): Pixowl Inc.
  • Genre(s): City-builder

Next up is something spooky for the kids who were always first in the queue at the Scholastic Book Fair. Goosebumps Horror Town is a cute but creepy city-builder with an array of Goosebumps easter eggs threaded throughout. Each main mission is based on a Goosebumps book, with themed quests and a lot of bonus fun that will please even the most casual Goosebumps fan.

This Goosebumps game offers lots to do and plenty of ways to get extra cash and resources, such as crafting disgusting treats and researching the town at the library. One of the best features in Goosebumps Horror Town is when players build monster dens and invite the creatures to rampage through the town, scaring the children! Fantastic frightening fun.

1 Pocket City

A Lovely City-Building Experience With Zero In-App Purchases

  • Platform(s): IOS, Android
  • Release: July 30, 2018
  • Developer(s): Codebrew Games
  • Genre(s): City-builder

Unlike all the games above where there is a glass ceiling of in-app purchases that prevents players from a faster progression, Pocket City is a game made by gamers, for gamers! The game puts the player in charge of a small town and gives them some resources to grow it.

As the player makes progress, maintaining a balance between industrial, commercial, and residential districts becomes more important. The small town in the beginning gradually grows into a metropolitan while the challenges become bigger and bigger. Pocket City almost feels like a minimal version of Cities: Skylines .

item.title: 7 Best Soulslike Games That Are Mostly Boss Fights
item.description:
Few genres manage to capture the attention and imagination of players across the world, like the soulslike genre. The dark lore, high-stakes difficulty, and for many titles, the boss fights, are all core components of this genre that help tie together some pretty disparate games into a coherent identity. Challenge is the keyword with soulslikes. The gameplay is a challenge, understanding the narrative is a challenge, building a character is a challenge.

But a good soulslike doesn't just have high difficulty. It has a reward for those that can overcome the difficulty - something that makes each struggle worthwhile. And what greater struggle is there than the almighty boss fight? What better reward can there be than watching some colossal foe finally fall by your hand? For players who want to skip the ambling around maps and get right to the boss fights, these soulslike titles keep the focus on imposing, difficult, capstone enemies.

7 Mortal Shell

A Focused, Wistful Soulslike Experience

Built around a tight, but incredibly satisfying group of weapons, Mortal Shell is one of the unique - and arguably one of the best - soulslike experiences out there. It is almost antiquated in its incredibly focused scope and overall small world design in an industry that prides itself on a 'bigger is better' approach to content.

Part of this small scale means that the game is predominately focused on one thing - boss fights. Each weapon is earned from defeating a boss, and the capstones for progress are similarly tied to intensive boss battles. Part of there being such an emphasis on only a handful of weapons - and several detailed boss fights - means that the animations and hitboxes in these battles often rival much larger and bigger budget games .

6 Black Myth: Wukong

A Huge Game With Colossal Boss Fights

One of the most ambitious and well-received soulslikes to come from somewhere that wasn't From Software in recent years, Black Myth allows players to truly integrate themselves and be immersed in the epic quest of this ancient and venerated tale. The core focus of this title, beyond the many well-designed weapons and animations, is the emphasis on spectacular, cinematic boss fights.

Players will find a very cathartic experience here with the layered and intensive boss fights being the main draw to continue exploring a dangerous, mournful world of myth and legend. Any soulslike fans would do well to give this game a try.

5 Eldest Souls

A Fast-Paced And Incredibly Satisfying Soulslike

This climactic, isometric soulslike is inspired by many classics in the genre, but brings its own incredibly distinctive aesthetic to the foreground. Eldest Souls tells a classic, high fantasy tale of one man and his fabled sword being the last hope of a dying world, but the gameplay is one a truly unique wavelength.

Each fast-paced boss battle has its own rules to adhere to, and as they comprise the bulk of the game, this is a soulslike that tests players' ability to adapt over raw damage output. For those that fall in love with the base game, even more bosses are available in the expansion that was released in 2022.

4 Titan Souls

Conquer Huge Slew Of Terrifying Bosses

Like many titles on this list - but with an especially compelling flair - Titan Souls is a game where the narrative is built around its most precious aspect - that being the boss fights. A lonesome hero is exploring an ancient world, and the guardians of this ancient, ruined world are the titular titans.

Each titan is an awe-inspiring display of power, and the adventures of the protagonist will take them into the farthest reaches of a sprawling, colossal kingdom of myth. This is an excellent example of a soulslike that focuses squarely on bosses from both a gameplay and lore perspective.

3 Ender Lilies: Quietus Of The Knights

An Incredibly Unique Mechanic Utilized In Boss Fights

Taking an altogether different stance on both the soulslike and metroidvania subgenres, Ender Lilies is a title where players utilize the souls of powerful knights to help a more fragile protagonist complete her quest. Each knight has their own powerful abilities that can help players get through the many difficult fights that make up the bulk of this game.

This is a fantastic title for those looking to try a different spin on boss-heavy soulslikes and metroidvanias, and beyond this, has an excellent, forboding aesthetic and art style that meshes perfectly with the darker storyline that's being told.

2 The Aquatic Adventure Of The Last Human

An Incredibly Unique Setting With Fantastic Boss Fights

A more obscure title within the soulslike genre, but one that is absolutely worth checking out, The Aquatic Adventure of the Last Human has a truly unique design philosophy that emphasizes the beauty - and the danger - of the deep ocean.

The bosses match the game's aquatic style, with terrifying deep sea creatures all posing their own unique threats as the focal point of the title. No game is quite like this seafaring, boss-focused soulslike, and players who are veterans of the genre will do especially well here.

1 Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice

A From Software Masterwork With An Emphasis On Difficult Boss Fights

As well-received, and as hugely influential, as the other modern titles from From Software, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice is a game that takes a more focused, skill-based approach to the classic soulslike formula. Players won't be relying on powerful gear here so much as their timing and reflexes.

The greatest test of these reflexes comes in the form of the boss battles that will continually test players throughout the game. Some of these are the quintessential puzzle bosses that almost every From Software title has, while some are challenges against hulking monsters, or duels against lethally skilled fighters - with each battle adding a new layer of characterization and lore to this fantastic game.
